. The island is around 8 kilometres across, and is a national park. Often described as "an island for the soul", this is the Baltic's most isolated island and it is a lovely place to unwind, watch the horizon and take long walks listening to the wind in the pine trees.

Through history, the island has occasionally been populated. Legend says that it was a base for pirates during the Middle Ages. In the 17th and 18th centuries there was sheep farming on the island, and later cattle and crop farming as well. Today, there is no itinerant population, except the hospitality and park crew.

World-renowned film director Ingmar Bergman recorded a feature documentary about the island in 1987.

On an island named after sand, you can expect the most stunning beaches in Sweden. There is some 30 kilometers of sandy beaches surrounding the island. In fact almost all of the island consists of sand, with some stone and gravel. However, most of the inland area is covered with pine forest, tall and breezy.

There is a small colony of grey seals on the island: make your way to Säludden and see if they're there. You may also spot forest hares, toads and several unusual species of beetles, some endemic to Gotska Sandön. There's also a rich variety of migratory birds, best viewed in springtime.

The trip takes a little over three hours - you may want to bring motion sickness medication. M/S Gotska Sandön is designed to land on sandy beaches, since the island has no harbour, but depending on the wind you might need to go ashore by dinghy. From the beach you will have to walk on foot to the campsite, between 1 and 9 kilometers away depending on where the captain decides to land (luggage is transported by tractor).

One of the few scheduled activities, and a popular one, is the daily evening prayer in the small chapel, built in 1894 and rebuilt in 1950 after a fire. A peaceful way to end a most likely peaceful day.

There are no shops on the island.

The café on the ship is the last restaurant you'll see for a while - you need to bring all the food you're going to eat yourself. Stock up in Nynäshamn before you go. If you stay in the hostel or in a tent there is a communal kitchen available.
